resources.string: Step 1: Select any downloaded language from the dropdown below:
Number of category icons per screen
Hello! you are using Jellow Communicator.
You are not connected to the Internet. Please turn on your Internet.

Jellow communicator is equipped with its own \'Serial Jellow keyboard\'. This keyboard was designed based on feedback from special educators and teachers and features alphabets placed in a serial manner starting form the alphabet \'A\'. The serial keyboard makes it easy for the user to anticipate the place of a particular alphabet on the keyboard and is especially very useful for children learning early literacy skills. Similarly, the keyboard also features numeral keys from 0–9 and symbols, which are most relevant to every day communication.
To enable a keyboard of your choice and make it as default, you need to complete 2 steps:
Step 1: Enable Keyboard from device settings
Step 2: Save Keyboard as default option
Caregiver\'s Contact number other than this device\'s sim number *

• Jellow remembers the user\'s \"most-used/preferred\" icons and displays them as the top choices on the screen

  • By resetting preferences, the icons will be set to the original order in which they were displayed the first time the application was opened

  • Do you want to reset preferences?

Jellow is a communicator using icons to enable speech and can be used by those learning to speak or those who have difficulty with speech. Jellow can also be used by toddlers and early learners to learn words and categories frequently used in their daily lives. Jellow\'s colourful and friendly icons can help children develop an association between pictures and their corresponding word labels. It is developed at IDC School of Design at the Indian Institute of Technology Bombay located in Mumbai. A novel Emotional Language Proto call or ELP was conceived and developed by the project investigators in order to enhance the language ability of Jellow. ELP represents the 6 expressive icons that form the core of the interface. Using these core icons, the child can communicate their likes, dislikes, and needs with others. Jellow is conceived as children-friendly with an easy-to-learn interface. The application is optimized for Android tablets.Jellow is currently available in English, Hindi, Bengali and Marathi. The current version of Jellow is _. The application is under further development. Therefore, if you have any suggestions for us, please submit it under the feedback tab or write to us at jellowcommunicator@gmail.com. Jellow is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-commercial Share Alike 4.0 International License. Work on Jellow is attributed to the Indian Institute of Technology Bombay. The content in this application comprising icons, layout, architecture, visual identity, translation, and the software codes can be shared and adopted but cannot be used for commercial purposes. When the content is used, we request you to acknowledge Indian Institute of Technology Bombay. Jellow is available for download at www dot jellow dot o r g. If interested in further developing the code, please write to Professor Ravi Poovaiah at ravi @ i i t b dot a c.in or at j e l l o w c o m m u n i c a t o r @ g m a i l . c o m
Jellow has 9 central category buttons and 6 expressive side buttons:
To speak using Jellow, the user first clicks on any category button and then on an expressive button in that order. For instance, Jellow will say, “I want to eat” using the selection below:
By double-clicking on a category button, the user can access further sub-categories:
The user can customize their profile and adjust the basic voice settings of the application by clicking on the top right corner of the screen:
Jellow can also be used to teach children sequential steps of daily activities. By clicking on any individual step, the user may view the expressive buttons:

To use Jellow in English, Hindi and Bengali, please activate \'Google text-to-speech (TTS)\' within \'Language\' settings of your device. Within Google TTS settings, first change the default language to preferred language and then download voice for preferred language through the \'Install voice data\' option
Jellow remembers the user’s “most-used or preferred” icons and displays them as the top choices on the screen
By resetting preferences, the icons will be set to the original order in which they were displayed the first time the application was opened
Do you want to reset preferences?
Please ensure an active Internet connection during the entire download process. In case the progress bar is stalled, kindly restart the app or try again
Kindly rate Jellow in all fields.
The application also has 6 expressive side buttons
The user first clicks on a category button and then on an expressive button
By double-clicking on a category button, user can access further categories and sub-categories
User can customize application settings by clicking on top right corner of the application
Now you are ready to get started with Jellow
(To be used for correspondence in case of an emergency involving the child.)
(To notify you about the release of Jellow updates)
Select a Language for Jellow. Required field
Please turn on internet and complete Step 3

Step 2: Check if voice data for _ is available on your device. If not please turn on internet and download voice data for selected language. In case process is stalled please check your internet connection and retry
Step 3: Set \'Google Text-to-speech (TTS)\' as default TTS engine and set _ as default language of the engine.
Step 4: Click \'Apply changes\' to set new language as default
You can follow the steps listed below to set a newly added language as the default for Jellow
Please complete Text-to-Speech engine setup given in this page
Selected language is already default language
Please check the \'Language\' settings of the app
Devices with active Google TTS engine: Please swipe to skip current step
Voice data not available. Please turn on internet and go to language settings of app.
Call permission is not available. Call permission is required to make a call in case of an emergency.
Please wait registration is in process…
Google TTS engine is not installed on your device. Do you want to install TTS engine?
Jellow will not work without Google Text-to-speech engine. Do you really want to exit?

Jellow is a communicator using icons to enable speech and can be used by those learning to speak or those who have difficulty with speech. Jellow can also be used by toddlers and early learners to learn words and categories frequently used in their daily lives. Jellow’s colourful and friendly icons can help children develop an association between pictures and their corresponding word labels.
It is developed at IDC School of Design at the Indian Institute of Technology Bombay located in Mumbai.

A novel Emotional Language Protocol or ELP was conceived and developed by the project investigators in order to enhance the language ability of Jellow. ELP represents the 6 expressive icons that form the core of the interface.
Using these core icons, the child can communicate their likes, dislikes, and needs with others.
Jellow is conceived as children-friendly with an easy-to-learn interface.
The application is optimized for Android tablets.
Jellow is currently available in English, Hindi, Bengali and Marathi.

The current version of Jellow is _. The application is under further development. Therefore, if you have any suggestions for us, please submit it under the feedback tab or write to us at jellowcommunicator@gmail.com."
Jellow is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-commercial Share Alike 4.0 International License.
Work on Jellow is attributed to the Indian Institute of Technology Bombay.
The content in this application comprising icons, layout, architecture, visual identity, translation, and the software codes can be shared and adopted but cannot be used for commercial purposes.
When the content is used, we request you to acknowledge Indian Institute of Technology Bombay.
Jellow is available for download at
If interested in further developing the code, please write to Professor Ravi Poovaiah at

Topiwala National Medical College and B.Y.L Nair Charitable Hospital (Departments of Psychiatry and Audiology and Speech Therapy)
On a scale of 1 to 5, please rate the following

The image shows a screenshot of the home page of Jellow. The home page contains a central grid of 9 icons called category buttons that are arranged in 3 rows and 3 columns. The 9 category buttons are “Greet and feel”, “Daily activities”, “Eating”, “Fun”, “Learning”, “People”, “Places, “Time and weather”, and “Help”. Below the category buttons are 3 navigation buttons of “Back”, “Home” and “keyboard” arranged in that order at the bottom of the home screen. On the right and left sides of the central category icons are 3 expressive icons each. To the left of the central grid are 3 expressive buttons of “Like”, “Yes” and “More” arranged from top to bottom in that order. To the right of the central grid, are the remaining 3 expressive buttons of “Don’t like”, “No” and “Less” arranged from top to bottom. On the top right corner of the home screen is visible a settings icon. In this image the central grid of 9 icons has been highlighted with all other buttons faded out.

This image again shows the screenshot of the home page of Jellow. In this image, the 6 expressive buttons arranged as 3 each of either side of the central category buttons have been highlighted with all other buttons faded out. To the left of the central grid of category buttons, arranged from top to bottom are the 3 expressive buttons of “Like” represented by a “Smiley face” icon, “Yes” represented by a “check mark” icon, and “More” represented by a “Plus sign” icon. To the right of the category buttons, arranged from top to bottom are the expressive icons of “Don’t like” represented by a sad face” icon, “No” represented by the, “cross” icon and “Less” represented by the, “Minus sign” icon. Also labeled in the image are the 3 navigational buttons at the bottom of the screen. From left to right these are “Back”, “Home”, and “Keyboard”.

This image has the home screen of Jellow with only 2 icons of “Eating” and “Yes” highlighted. The rest of the buttons are faded out. The image shows that to speak using Jellow, user has to first click on any category button, for instance, “Eating” and then on an expressive button, for example, “Yes”. In this way the user can speak using Jellow

This image has the home screen of Jellow with only the icon for “Eating” highlighted. The rest of the buttons on the level 1 screen are faded out. The image shows a finger double-clicking on the, “Eating” icon to access sub-categories within this main category.

This image shows a screenshot of Jellow sub-categories accessed by double-clicking on the, “Eating” icon as shown in the image above. The Level 2 sub-category icons visible in the central grid arranged in a 3 by 3 grid format are “Breakfast”, “Lunch/Dinner”, “Sweets”, “Snacks”, “Fruits”, “Drinks”, “Cutlery”, and “Add-ons”. The image shows the user’s finger double-clicking on “Breakfast” icon to access further sub-options.

This image shows a screenshot of the Level 3 screen accessed by clicking on the, “Breakfast” sub-category icon within the main category of “Eating”. The central grid icons visible on this screen are “Bread”, “Cornflakes”, “Aaloo Poori”, “Eggs”, “Poha””, “Upma”, “Khichdi”, and “Idli”. In addition the expressive icons on either sides of the screen, the navigational buttons at the bottom of the screen, and settings icon on the top right corner of the screen are also visible.

This image shows the home screen of Jellow with a drop-down at the top right corner of Jellow. This drop-down shows options of “Profile”, “About Jellow”, “Tutorial”, “Keyboard Control”, “Language”, “Settings”, “Reset preferences”, and “Feedback”. By clicking on any of these options the user can customize the app’s settings to their needs.

This is a screenshot of a sequential activity within Jellow. The image specifically shows the, “Toilet” sequence that can be accessed within the, “Daily activities” main category. The screen shows icons of 3 sequential steps involved in going to the toilet. Step 1 is “Pulling pants down”, Step 2 is “Sit on toilet”, and Step 3 is “Wash bottom”. There are arrows between these individual icons to indicate the sequential nature of the process. Below the 3 sequence icons are 2 buttons of “Previous” and “Next”. The, “Previous” button is disabled since this is the first screen of steps within the, “Toilet” sequence. A finger is shown clicking on the, “Next” button in order to move to the next screen depicting the next set of steps within this sequence. The expressive buttons are not visible in this image. The navigational buttons of “Back”, “Home”, and “Keyboard” are visible at the bottom of the screen.

This image is the same as the one shown above depicting the first 3 steps within the, “Toilet” sequence within “Daily activities”. However in this image, the user’s finger is seen clicking on the Step 2 icon corresponding to “Sit on toilet”. By clicking on this icon, the expressive buttons are now visible on either sides of the screen within the application.

The image is made up of 3 screenshots of the, “Text to speech output” and “Google TTS voice data” settings within a user’s device. In the first image corresponding to “Text-to-speech output”, there are 2 preferred engines visible, first, the, “Samsung Text-to-Speech engine” and second, the, “Google Text-to-Speech engine”. The user is seen to select the, “Google Text-to-Speech engine”as the first step.
The second image corresponds to the second step in this process where the user is seen to now click on the, “Gear” symbol corresponding to the, “Settings” of the, “Google Text-to-Speech engine”

The third image is the third step in this process where now the user is at the, “Google TTS voice data” screen. This screen provides multiple voice options including “French (France)”, “German (Germany)”, “Hindi (India)”, “Hungarian (Hungary)”, and “Indonesian (Indonesia)”. The, “Hindi (India) voice” option is highlighted and shows an option of “Voice set 1” with a size of 19MB that is available for download. The user’s finger is seen to click on the download icon for the voice set 1 for the, “Hindi (India)voice”.
Caregiver\'s Contact number other than this device\'s sim number. Required field
(Choose the person who will be using Jellow on this device)

In the first image corresponding to “Text-to-speech output”, there are 2 preferred engines visible, first, the, “Samsung Text-to-Speech engine” and second, the, “Google Text-to-Speech engine”. The user is seen to select the “Google Text-to-Speech engine”as the first step.
The second image corresponds to the second step in this process where the user is seen to now click on the, “Gear” symbol corresponding to the, “Settings” of the, “Google Text-to-Speech engine

The third image is the third step in this process where now the user is at the, “Google TTS voice data” screen. This screen provides multiple voice options including “French (France)”, “German (Germany)”, “Hindi (India)”, “Hungarian (Hungary)”, and “Indonesian (Indonesia)”. The “Hindi (India) voice” option is highlighted and shows an option of “Voice set 1” with a size of 19MB that is available for download. The user’s finger is seen to click on the download icon for the voice set 1 for the, “Hindi (India)voice”.
Language selected in Jellow is different from that of your device output language. Would you like to change your device language ?
Please use your device’s volume buttons to change speech speed.
Please use your device’s volume buttons to change voice pitch
Please use your device’s volume buttons to change speech volume

“The image below shows the 3 steps involved in setting up the Google text-to-speech engine that is used by Jellow. The image is made up of 3 screenshots of the, “Text to speech output” and “Google TTS settings” within a user’s device. In the first image corresponding to “Text-to-speech output”, there are 2 preferred engines visible, first, the, “Samsung Text-to-Speech engine” and second, the, “Google Text-to-Speech engine”. The user is seen to select the, “Google Text-to-Speech engine” as the first step.
The second image corresponds to the second step in this process where the user is seen to now click on the, “Gear” symbol corresponding to the, “Settings” of the, “Google Text-to-Speech engine”

The third image is the third step in this process where now the user is at the, “Google TTS options” screen. The second item on this screen which is a toggle switch for “Use Wi-Fi only” has been highlighted in this image. The user is asked to turn off or disable this switch in this step.”

The third image corresponds to the third step in this process where the user is seen to now click on the, “Language\" option on the Google TTS voice data page. The user is seen to set \"Hindi(India)\" as the default language of the Google Text-to-Speech engine.
2. Go to \"Settings\" for Google TTS Engine
Go to settings of Google TTS and turn off \'Use Wi-Fi only\' by tapping below \'TTS SETTINGS\' button. If option is already disabled, please skip this step.
Please complete above process to turn off \'Use Wi-Fi only\' option
Please follow the steps below to setup Text-to-speech engine
Voice data not available. Please turn on internet and complete Step 2
Registration process is failed, please retry.

The Visual accessibility feature of Jellow now allows users with additional visual difficulties including low vision or blindness to use Jellow and communicate effectively with others. It utilizes the \'Talk back\' feature on the Android smartphone to help navigate through the application. With \'Talk back\' switched on in the user\'s device, the user will now be able to get audio input describing everything they touch on the screen. The user can also assign custom gestures or use the default gestures of \'Talk back\' as they interact with Jellow. For example, a right swipe gesture will allow the user to sequentially scroll through icons on the screen. Similarly, double tapping anywhere on the screen will allow the user to select an icon of their choice.
